posts.post_content:
I love the concept for the flavor behind this card, but it's pretty weak unfortunately.  
  
I'm not entirely content with realization of flavor to functionality though.  
The flavor issues I see (as well as the changes I'd make to fix them) are the following:  
  
- **Make it a *Horse Construct***:  
If a creature that's based on the Trojan Horse isn't a construct, I don't know what is.  
  
- **Make the effect not just check the controller, but the owner as well**:  
The flavor gets screwed up once you take control of the horse (e.g. with [Homeward Path](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Homeward Path)). The effect still triggers and your opponent will get the tokens instead. But those tokens represent the soldiers you hid in your fake present. If you take it back, those soldiers shouldn't suddenly turn against you.   
  
- **Make it unable to block, or a noncreature artifact entirely**:  
(Lord\_of\_Tresserhorn already pointed that one out)  
It's an inanimate object after all. It shouldn't be able to block, especially not th... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

But those tokens represent the soldiers you hid in your fake present. If you take it back, those soldiers shouldn't suddenly turn against you.

- Make it unable to block, or a noncreature artifact entirely:

Posted By: Dargenom (3/19/2014 5:43:53 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Looking at [Goblin Assault](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Goblin Assault), [Bitterblossom](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Bitterblossom), and  [Honden of Life's Web](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name= Honden of Life's Web), this card doesn't seem all that bad. It costs 1 more than the Assault and gives the opponent a [Steel Wall](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Steel Wall), but since you're getting a token every turn, you can pretty quickly overrun them. It doesn't play nice with any 3-power creatures you have, but in a token deck one more blocker won't slow you down too much.  
  
The real downsides are that you can't attack with anything that has 4+ power without losing your tokens, the Horse doesn't survive through wrarth effects, and anyone playing sac effects will just laugh in your face.  
  
It's no [Bitterblossom](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Bitterblossom), but hey, it's colorless and the Blossom kinda made Standard revolve around itself for a fair while. Plus, this thing has some crazy political potential in mutliplayer.
posts.html:
Looking at Goblin Assault, Bitterblossom, and Honden of Life's Web, this card doesn't seem all that bad. It costs 1 more than the Assault and gives the opponent a Steel Wall, but since you're getting a token every turn, you can pretty quickly overrun them. It doesn't play nice with any 3-power creatures you have, but in a token deck one more blocker won't slow you down too much.

The real downsides are that you can't attack with anything that has 4+ power without losing your tokens, the Horse doesn't survive through wrarth effects, and anyone playing sac effects will just laugh in your face.

It's no Bitterblossom, but hey, it's colorless and the Blossom kinda made Standard revolve around itself for a fair while. Plus, this thing has some crazy political potential in mutliplayer.

posts.post_content:
Everyone is talking about their [Zedruu](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Zedruu) decks, but you can also put it into a [Glissa, the Traitor](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Glissa, the Traitor) deck.  
  
When it inevitably dies (blocking Glissa, or sacrificed, or something), it counts as a creature an opponent controls. Then Glissa's ability triggers and she gets to pull it out of your graveyard for another go-round. It's hilarious.
posts.html:
